choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Function residual capacity (FRC) = Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) + Residual volume (RV).

Lung Capacities

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath.

Other options: 

Option B: Residual volume - The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort.

Option D: Expiratory capacity - TV + ERV

Lung volumes, capacities, and their combinations are being tested year after year in the various competitive exams.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.5 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24h urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/ml. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. The most likely mode of clinical diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pituitary diabetes insipidus.

Approach to the question

  • A 24-hour urine volume greater than 3 liters is suggestive of polyuria.
  • Urine osmolarity < 300 mOsm/ L is suggestive of DI or primary polydipsia.
  • ADH assay < 1pg/mL = Primary polydipsia or central DI.
  • Finally, the absence of a pituitary bright spot in the MRI brain is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus.

Other options:

  • In nephrogenic DI, the ADH levels will be greater than 1pg/mL.
  • In the case of primary polydipsia, a pituitary bright spot will be observed.
  • In solute loss (mannitol or hypertonic saline infusion), urine osmolality is greater than 300 mOsm/L.

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by _______
questions.solution:
Herpes viruses typically cause punched-out ulcers.

For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and from the base of the ulcer in cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Findings in HSV ulcer

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies

CMV causes shallow ulcerations and characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions within capillary endothelium and stromal cells.

Candidiasis, in its most advanced form, is characterized by the adherent, gray-white pseudomembranes.

Acid, as in reflux esophagitis, may show a simple hyperaemia on endoscopy.

Image: Ulcer of herpes simplex—Multinucleated squamous cells at the margin of the ulcer with dense eosinophilic intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions with thickened nuclear membrane and clear halo with nuclear molding.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection of the esophagus is usually observed in patients who are immunocompetent and also seen in patients who are immunocompromised.

It occurs most frequently in those receiving immunosuppressive agents, such as solid organ and bone marrow transplant recipients.

The above image shows HSV esophagitis in a young immuno competent individual.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques

HSV: Herpes simplex virus

CMV: Cytomegalovirus

The quadruple screening test is ideally done in the second trimester, during 15-20 weeks of gestation. The most accurate values are seen during 16-18 weeks of gestation. 

It is the measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG and inhibin-A. 

The abnormalities seen on quadruple screen are tabulated below:

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

questions.text: Hyperacute graft rejection is commonly seen in the transplants of:-
questions.solution:
Hyperacute graft rejection is seen in the kidney.

Hyperacute rejection:-

Hyperacute rejection occurs usually within the first few hours post-transplantation and is mediated by preformed antibodies against ABO or MHC antigens of the graft. Once the antibodies bind to the transplanted tissues, rejection can be caused either by activation of the complement system, which results in the chemotactic attraction of granulocytes and the triggering of inflammatory circuits, or by ADCC (Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity).

Pathological features of hyperacute rejection are the following:

  • This is associated with the formation of massive intravascular platelet aggregates leading to thrombosis, ischemia, and necrosis.
  • The hyperacute rejection episodes are irreversible and invariably results in graft loss. With proper cross-matching techniques, this type of rejection is almost 100% avoidable.
  • The hyperacute rejection by antibodies to all human cellular antigens is the major limitation of xenogeneic transplantation (e.g., pig to human).

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

 

Mechanism

Morphology

T-cell-mediated

Acute

Seen within the initial months after transplantation;

Clinical and biochemical signs of organ failure;

Cytokines secreted by activated CD4+ T cells.

Increased vascular permeability and  accumulation of mononuclear cells (lymphocytes and macrophages)

Chronic

Lymphocytes reacting against alloantigens in the vessel wall

Cytokines that induce local inflammation and may stimulate the proliferation of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells.

The vascular lesions and T-cell reactions cause parenchymal fibrosis.

B-cell-mediated

  

Hyperacute

Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient

Endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi, Neutrophils, thrombotic occlusion of the capillaries, and fibrinoid necrosis in arterial walls

Acute antibody-mediated

Antidonor antibodies produced after transplantation

Complement-dependent cytotoxicity, inflammation, and antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.

The initial target of these antibodies in rejection seems to be the graft vasculature

Inflamation of capillaries

Deposition of the complement breakdown product C4d

Chronic antibody-mediated

Develops insidiously, without preceding acute rejection, and primarily affects vascular components.

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.solution:
The image shows inflammation and hypopyon. These signs, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery, suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis. The management is to administer intravitreal antibiotics.

The majority of patients with postoperative endophthalmitis present with an acute onset and within seven days after surgery.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.

The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and decrease in vision.

The patient classically presents with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis, because they do not reach sufficiently high intra ocular concentrations for effective treatment of severe intra-ocular infections such as endophthalmitis.

Intra-vitreal antibiotics should be started empirically, antibiotics commonly used in combination are ceftazidime, which will most of the gram-negative organisms (including pseudomonas aeruginosa) and vancomycin to address gram- positive cocci (including methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus).

Other treatments:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Cycloplegia
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: Identify the thickened nerve marked in the arrow in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve and the thickened nerve visible below the great auricular nerve is the transverse cervical nerve.

Great auricular nerve:

It is the largest ascending branch of cervical plexus and arises from the second and the third cervical spinal nerves.

It winds over the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and ascends upwards. On reaching the parotid gland it divides into the anterior and posterior branches:

  • The anterior branch supplies the facial skin over the parotid gland and joins the facial nerve in the gland.
  • The posterior branch supplies the skin over mastoid process, lower part of back of the auricle, lobule and concha.

Clinical considerations:

  • The nerve can be thickened in conditions like leprosy and can be palpated over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (as seen in the above image)
  • The skin over the face is supplied by the branches of trigeminal nerve. The great auricular nerve is the only nerve which is not a branch of trigeminal nerve and supplies the facial skin over the angle of mandible.
  • An aberrant connection between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands (great auricular nerve) is considered to be the part of the anatomical basis of the Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating).

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Alzheimer's disease?

choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.solution:
Nucleus of Meynert is affected in Alzheimer's disease.

Pathological features of Alzheimer's disease:

Microscopically, there are neuritic plaques containg amyloid beta, neurofibrillary tangles containing phosphorylated tau protein, and amyloid beta accumulation in the blood vessel walls of the cortex and leptomeninges.

Biochemically, there is reduction of acetylcholine, and a degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert that project throughout the cortex. There is also noradrenergic and serotonergic depletion due to degeneration of brain stem nuclei such as the locus ceruleus and the dorsal raphe. 

 

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • MMSE < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4, Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: Hallucinations
  • Dyspraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • Urinary incontinence

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles, neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: Memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: Donepezil, Galantamine, Rivastigmine.

questions.text: The X-ray given below is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows folds that run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen, which is called a feline esophagus and is seen in reflux esophagitis. 

Feline oesophagus is also known as oesophageal shiver, refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower oesophagus on a double contrast barium swallow. The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux and is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae with resultant shortening of the oesophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

Radiologic features: The folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oesophageal lumen. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic oesophagus.

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic oesophagitis (wherein the folds will be permanent and be associated with strictures).

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray image are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accident). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

The radiographic image shows oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum known as involucrum. 

The characteristic radiographic features of other conditions given are:

Osteogenic sarcoma - Sun-burst appearance, Codman's triangle

Ewing's sarcoma - Onion skin appearance

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst - Double density fluid levels  and intralesional septation

Related Pearl: Classical radiological appearance of bone tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance/

codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma but can be seen in any Malignant lesion

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma but can be seen in any Malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis 

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor,adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance/shepherds

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors(chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn,punctate or comma shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Chicken wire pattern of calcification 

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors(osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment or trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double density fluid levels  and intralesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign or corduroy or jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangiona

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

questions.text: Verruca vulgaris is most commonly caused by __________
questions.solution:
Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by Human Papilloma Virus -2 (HPV-2) but is also to the closely related types 27, 57 and
types 1 and 4.

  • Common warts are usually symptomless, but may be tender on the palmar aspects of the fingers, when fissured or when growing beneath the nail plate.
  • Viral warts show acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, usually with the characteristic feature of koilocytosis of upper keratinocytes. Most of them also show papillomatosis.
  • These present as firm papules with a rough horny surface. They range in size from less than 1 mm to over 1 cm in diameter.
  • These are most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers, and, in children on the knees, but may occur anywhere on the skin.
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed - new lesions along the sites of trauma.
  • Products containing salicylic acid with or without lactic acid are effective patient-applied treatments. Cryotherapy can also be effectively used for periungual warts.

Image: Verruca Vulgaris

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
In the above graph, LD50 = 400, and ED50 = 100; TI = LD50 / ED50

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

The Therapeutic Index (TI) (also referred to as therapeutic ratio) is a comparison of the amount of a therapeutic agent that causes the toxicity (e.g. lethal dose in 50% of subjects, LD50) to the amount that causes the therapeutic effect (e.g. efficacious dose in 50% of subjects, ED50).

The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

LD50 (median lethal dose) or TD50 (median toxic dose)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die
  • Larger the LD50 safer the drug
  • In humans, TD50 is considered 
  • TD50: the dose of a drug that causes a toxic response in 50% of the population

ED50 : (median effective dose)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: Occipitomental view with closed mouth is called as:
questions.solution:
Occipitomental view with closed mouth is called as water’s view.

Water's view: The patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. Structures seen in water’s view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Intratemporal fossa

Occipito mental view with open mouth is called Pierre's view. The mouth is kept open, which allows visualising the sphenoid sinus.

 

Related Pearl: Radiographic views for paranasal sinuses

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

Score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused

Score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to painful stimulus only.

Score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
A thirsty child signifies some dehydration, not severe dehydration. 

In severe dehydration the child is:

  • Drowsy, lethargic or unconscious
  • Drinks poorly or not able to drink
  • Sunken eyes
  • Skin pinch goes back very slowly
